conclusion: We have a beam of blue light traveling from point A in the air towards the boundary between air and water. The light ray enters the water at point O1. The light ray then passes through point B in the water. Point O is the intersection of the line AB with the boundary between air and water. We need to determine if O1 is to the right of O.

When light travels from a medium with a lower refractive index to a medium with a higher refractive index (like from air to water), it bends towards the normal (the line perpendicular to the boundary at the point of incidence). The angle of incidence (θi) is the angle between the incident ray and the normal. The angle of refraction (θr) is the angle between the refracted ray and the normal.

premise: Since the light ray travels from air to water, the refractive index of water is greater than that of air.
conclusion: The light ray will bend towards the normal when it enters the water.

premise: The light ray will bend towards the normal when it enters the water.
conclusion: The refracted ray will be closer to the normal compared to the incident ray.

premise: Point O1 is where the light ray enters the water. The refracted ray will be closer to the normal than the incident ray.
conclusion: The refracted ray will intersect the boundary at a point closer to the normal than the incident ray would have intersected the boundary without refraction.

premise: If the incident ray AO intersects the boundary at point O, and the refracted ray intersects the boundary at point O1, and since the refracted ray is closer to the normal.
conclusion: O1 must be to the left of O.
